{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3553262,"name":"EricRehder","username":"EricRehder","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/7ab992/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-10T21:17:28.643Z","cooked":"

What resistances are expected between the battery and PDH?

Our bot competed at Port Hueneme 10 days ago where we suffered an enormous amount of brownouts. This was new to our team. We would start with a battery ~12.5V and then at the very start of a match get hit with brownouts where the motors would be turning on/off and our pigeon angle would get lost. After the match we could check the logs and see the PDH voltage dropping to 9 or 8V. We are running a 8 NEO 1.1 swerve bot. This would have a current spike when starting and then stabilize at ~150A with a voltage 9 to 8 V. When stopped the battery would instantly recover to 12.5V. This was found on at least 5 different batteries used.

In order to reproduce the brownout we need to run the motors at full power which was very hard to achieve in the pit or practice area. In the last week we have cleaned up multiple issues but have not found root cause. Putting in motor current limits down to 20A stabilizes the motor controllers but we are still losing the pigeon2. And the swerve drive direction jumps around. We believe the pigeon2 loses power while the bot is rotating and loses its calibration. CTRE indicates pigeon2 would function to 6V.

The battery voltage recovers with low current draw indicating its not power loss but voltage drop across a resistance. I got this heater to use as a ~50A electrical load. My plan is to plug this into the PDH and trace the voltage from battery to heater wire. We are using the typical SB50 and 6AWG battery connections into the main breaker and then the PDH. What resistances are ‚Äúnormal‚Äù across these connections?

What else should I be looking at?

This is a crazy thought, but is it possible you have the motors incorrect on one of your swerve modules where the steering motor is being called as a drive motor and vice versa? If the voltage recovers immediately after you stop moving, you may have motors fighting against each other.

We had a team have this same issue this weekend, and they were having trouble diagnosing because every time they‚Äôd release their joysticks, their steering axes would move. Easy way to debug is drive your robot on the cart full speed forward, then just disable the robot while driving. Ensure all your wheels are actually pointing the same direction. This team had 1 module not pointing in the right direction, causing all of their issues.

For your proscribed root cause I think your procedure is sound.

I dont have absolute numbers for you, many of the contact resistance points can be looked-up like the SB50 Anderson terminals contact resistance. Presuming on the order of milliohms for crimped joints, etc‚Ä¶Overall for your situation I would expect to see a smoking gun of most of the voltage drop across a particular set of points indicating your problem area.

A point to check maybe quickly is your main breaker. Is it OPTIFUSE brand that comes in the Kit Of Parts? There is documentation on CD of many teams experiencing a higher than expected failure rate of those devices, a spot-check there would be good.

Now there are other root-causes on the fishbone diagram for your robots symptoms as @RockRGI and @Thad_House have indicated one.

Another is: how old are your batteries? One failure mode of lead acid batteries is reduced capacity. This can manifest in the current/voltage relationship you describe - looks fine open circuit but put a load on it and it drops severely. Given 5 different batteries give you similar behavior its less likely that this is the problem, but it is one bone on the fishbone.

Just in case you haven‚Äôt (you didn‚Äôt mention it), check all of your connections, especially on the mains circuit.

That heater sounds like a good test. I would recommend removing the insulation from a battery‚Äôs terminals so you can check to see if the voltage AT THE BATTERY drops significantly under load. If it does, your problem is the battery itself.

For anyone else: a fair dummy load we made once was to take two ‚Äúpractice‚Äù grade motors (If you have CIMs lying around and you‚Äôre brushless, there‚Äôs your answer) and install them in the same gearbox. Use a breaker, and wire them opposite directions. It should only take a second or so per connection to figure out if your voltage drop is from inside the battery or across the wiring/connectors, and larger motors can certainly stand a second of stall without damage.

When checking your main power wiring, check what I highlighted in this post.

High Battery Voltage Causing Brownout Electrical
As others have stated, the voltage rise is due to a motor operating in the regeneration mode. The battery should be able to absorb this energy and prevent a significant rise in the system voltage. Please pop the contacts out of the SB50 housing for the battery in question and on your robot. Look for copper color in the areas highlighted in green. This would indicate that the silver plating that reduces the contact resistance has worn off. If the highlighted area is rough, the contact resistance ‚Ä¶

EricRehder:

After the match we could check the logs and see the PDH voltage dropping to 9 or 8V. We are running a 8 NEO 1.1 swerve bot. This would have a current spike when starting and then stabilize at ~150A with a voltage 9 to 8 V. When

Could you talk a little more about your startup current spike and stabilized current at ~150A? How big was that spike, and are you seeing a continuous 150A draw during a match?

When you current limit your motors to 20A, what total current draw and voltage are you seeing?

Running 8-9v at 150A sounds plausible, and I wouldn‚Äôt necessarily expect brownouts to occur until the voltage is lower.

Replying to several comments

RockRGI: ‚Äúyou may have motors fighting against each other.‚Äù ‚Äì confirmed not an issue

Thad_House: ‚Äú Ensure all your wheels are actually pointing the same direction‚Äù ‚Äì confirmed not an issue

Jwal: ‚ÄúIs it OPTIFUSE brand that comes in the Kit Of Parts? There is documentation on CD of many teams experiencing a higher than expected failure rate of those devices, a spot-check there would be good.‚Äù-Yes Optifuse, but it seems OK. Will keep an eye on it.

Jwal: ‚Äúhow old are your batteries? Given 5 different batteries give you similar behavior its less likely that this is the problem‚Äù ‚Äì agreed. Same behavior on lightly used year old batteries and new batteries.

JoeT ‚ÄúCould you talk a little more about your startup current spike and stabilized current at ~150A? How big was that spike, and are you seeing a continuous 150A draw during a match?‚Äù- My drivers tend to be erratic and difficult to get a steady current. I‚Äôve focused on a test run with a fairly steady 150A draw for~3 sec where the battery voltage dropped from 12.5 down to ~8.5V. Focusing in on these logs is my major next step.

JoeT ‚ÄúRunning 8-9v at 150A sounds plausible, and I wouldn‚Äôt necessarily expect brownouts to occur until the voltage is lower.‚Äù- great to know. One of the challenges is understanding what is normal.

I got the 12V heater to use as a load to test the electronics. It worked nicely. But no smoking gun. I‚Äôll shift to battery quality, test logs, and motor current limiting. Here is what I found in the load test

  • Battery just off the charger, no cool down, so likely skin charge present
  • Battery beak: 112%, 0A 13.152V, 1A 13.127V, 18A 12.897V, internal resistance 0.017 Ohm
  • 12 V heater connected to PDH through a Rev 40A breaker. The heater is rated at 600W which would be ~50A, but we didn‚Äôt measure the current to verify.
  • Connect battery and turn on the 12V heater
  • Measure voltage across the battery posts 12.52V
  • Measure voltages down the positive connections (calc the resistance assuming 50A)
  • 0mV (0 mOhm): Battery post to Cu fitting
  • 20 mV (0.4mOhm): Cu fitting at battery to wire-SB50 crimp
  • 5.1mV (0.1mOhm): Across the SB50
  • 7.0mV (0.1mOhm): SB50 to post of main breaker
  • 23.7mV (0.5mOhm): Across posts of the main breaker
  • 2.3mV (0.05mOhm): post of main breaker to input of the PDH
  • 130.0mV (2.6mOhm): PDH input to PDH output to the heater
  • 11.09V: measure positive to negative at the PDH output
  • Measurements on the negative connections
  • 21.3mV (0.4mOhm): missed measurement of the PDH output to input
  • 9.7mV (0.2mOhm): PDH input to the SB50
  • 3.4mV (0.07mOhm): Across the SB50
  • 23.0mV (0.5mOhm): SB50 to battery post
  • 11.3V measured across the battery terminals
  • Repeat the battery beak: 52%, 18A 12.064V

The data is complicated as the battery voltage and test current were dropping through the test. But I‚Äôm looking for big losses and will ignore that. This indicates 257mV drop across the connection between the battery posts and a PDH output at 50A. With hard driving 4 motors at 50A each this would be a 528mV drop. We are seeing a much bigger voltage drop. The 2.6mOhm resistance of the 40A breaker is higher than I‚Äôd like. We‚Äôll monitor that, but its not driving brownouts.

Anything look like trouble in the above?

Now to focus more on battery quality and limiting motor currents.

Good assessment that although calculations based on these measurements are useful in a relative sense they are not absolute without controlling for the changing battery voltage during the duration of the test.

Nothing here jumps out to me as obvious as I hoped - I agree that the PDH input to PDH output measurement is higher than I hoped, but also may be normal as that path (depending on exactly where you measured and which output was used), could contain the following resistances:

  1. Input wire to WAGO terminal
  2. WAGO terminal to PCB terminal
  3. PCB trace
  4. PCB-to-Fuse A board terminal
  5. Fuse A board terminal to fuse/breaker terminal
  6. Your Fuse/breaker and all its internals
  7. Fuse terminal to Fuse B board terminal
  8. Fuse B board terminal to PCB
  9. PCB output trace 1
  10. PCB-to-Sense resistor A terminal
  11. PCB Sense resistor itself
  12. Sense resistor B terminal to PCB trace
  13. PCB output trace 2
  14. PCB-to-WAGO Output terminal resistance
  15. WAGO output terminal to output wire resistance

Overall the goal it for the total of all of those to be a minimum for maximum power delivery to the output.

I‚Äôll check if I can measure a similar path in a PDH over the next few days, but to see 130mŒ© is not entirely surprising/out of the ballpark of expectations.

Rereading your original post, it would not be unexpected to experience a brownout near the end of a match if you were hitting the battery particularly hard and had many motors/operating mechanisms or joints.

But to experience a perceived brownout at the beginning of a match is more unexpected.

I like your next troubleshooting steps of measuring/logging motor current and voltage data, and then looking into your battery health although I am less suspicious of battery health as I am interested in log data (current/voltage/power used over time, interested in the shape and duration of the transient power spikes).

EricRehder:

Battery beak: 112%, 0A 13.152V, 1A 13.127V, 18A 12.897V, internal resistance 0.017 Ohm

If we believe the Battery Beak internal resistance report of 0.017 Ohms, you would expect a voltage drop of 2.55v internal to the battery (0.017Ohms * 150A). With a 12.5v no-load voltage, you‚Äôll see ~10v at the battery at the 150A load. With a 10v maximum before you cross the first wire, measuring 8v-9v voltage at the PDH seems reasonable, and is in line with voltage measurements we‚Äôve seen in our hardware in competition.

What‚Äôs harder to understand is why your Pigeon 2 is browning out. How does the Pigeon 2 connect to power?

You need to look at actual the Voltage applied to your heater. You can have a significant resistance in the PDH terminals if the strip length isn‚Äôt right. You will only see it if you look at either the PDH‚Äôs own voltage measurement, or tag a meter onto a breaker port.

We got a resistance of 0.015 Ohm for a 3/8" strip length.

2022 REV Control System Electronics Reviews Technical Discussion
Yeah, I‚Äôd prefer to see a lugged power input too. We had a lot of challenges with the power input and 4 AWG wire. MOST of the issue was the kids not stripping it long enough; the strip length is out in ‚ÄúOMG that‚Äôs long‚Äù territory. At 1/2" strip length we got a connection resistance around 0.015 Ohm; as much as the battery itself. The bot worked fine that way, just browned out under hard driving. Another thing that would help is a well designed mechanical clamping method for the cables. Our‚Ä¶

Hey all, appreciate the many different thoughts to help guide us.

First on the Pigeon. We found that a calibration helped a lot. I‚Äôm not sure why, or what that did, but that greatly improved the stability. I was many weeks since the team went through the calibration routine. Second we found a loose connection feeding the VRM so the Pigeon was loosing power once in a while. Brownout yes but completely different from a battery drain issue.

We constrained our motors down to 40A and that has prevented our brownouts and keeps the drivestation voltage above 10V (at least with a reasonably fresh battery). Many teams function OK with limits of 60-80A just fine. We‚Äôll keep looking at this. And we are getting much smarter in our log reviews.
